channel.title: Uberflip Help Center Articles - Help Center Resources
channel.description: Latest articles from Uberflip Help Center

item.title: Internal: Draft and approve internal help articles
item.description:
Got knowledge you think will be useful to your team or others at Uberflip? Document it in our internal help center using the steps outlined below.Â 

Looking to have a public facing article drafted? Request a new public article using the steps here.Â 

Before you begin

  • If you havenâ€™t already, familiarize yourself with the Help Center style basics to ensure your article is consistent with others

Draft an article

  1. In a new or existing Zendesk ticket, open the Knowledge Capture app
    (Click the magnifyingÂ glass icon below the reply field)
  2. Click the Create Knowledge (+) button in the Knowledge Capture app
  3. Select a template

  4. Add a title (starting with "Internal:") and content to the article, following the structure of the template
    Note: Every article is different. While the template is a great outline to start with, change the article structure as needed to suit your article.
  5. In the right side panel, select your article settings and categories. For internal articles, it will be:Â 
    1. Managed By: Admins
    2. Visible to: Internal
    3. Publish in section: Internal Documentation > Internal Articles For Review
    4. Author: You
    5. Labels: [Labels are like tags on an article. If you think Uberflippers may search using keywords not used in your article, add those words as labels.]
  6. Click Save
    Note: The article created is a duplicate of the template; it does not overwrite the template.
  7. Inform your team lead that there is a new article waiting for review. Include the article title.Â 

Your article is now saved as a draft in the Internal Articles For Review section of the internal Help Center.Â 

Approve an article (Team Leads)Â 

Has a team member let you know they've written a new article? Here's how to review and publish it.Â Â 

  1. Log into the Zendesk Guide admin panelÂ 
  2. Search for the article that's been created
  3. Review the article, considering:Â 
    • Writing and grammar
    • Style guide
    • Template compliance (within reason)
    • Duplicate or similar articles
    • Accuracy
  4. Make edits or, in a third party tool like Slack or Google Docs, ask the author to make needed adjustments
    Note: See how an article will look once published by clicking Preview in Help Center in the right side panel (below Save button).Â 
  5. Once adjustments are made and the article is ready to be published, click the drop down next to the Save button in the top left.Â 
  6. Click Publish

The article is now live in the internal Help Center!

item.title: Internal: Help Center style basics
item.description:
Writing for the Uberflip Help Center? Uberflip has company wide content guidelines, but this guide quickly outlines some basic conventions that apply directly to Uberflip help articles.Â 

Grammar quick tips

  • Use American english (e.g. "color" over colour)
  • Prefer contractions (e.g. "youâ€™ll" over "you will")
  • Avoid unnecessarily complex words (ex. "chat" over "confabulate")
  • Prefer active voiceÂ 
  • Use the least amount of words/sentences needed to convey your messageÂ 

Titles and headingsÂ 

Title and headings at Uberflip use sentence case, meaning only the first letter and proper nouns are capitalized.Â 

Example:
Embed a YouTube video into a blog post

Unless necessary, avoid using â€˜How toâ€™ and gerunds (-ing) in titles and headings.

Example:
Incorrect: Embedding a YouTube video into a blog post
Incorrect: How to embed a YouTube video into a blog post
Correct: Embed a YouTube video into a blog post

Titles

When creating an article in Zendesk, there will be a dedicated field for your title.Â 

HeadingsÂ 

Help articles use headings H2-H4 headings as needed (youâ€™re not likely to need an H1 heading in a help article).Â 

H2Â 

  • Used for article sections
  • Any H2 heading in an article will appear in the table of contents when the article is published

H3 & H4

  • Smaller than H2 respectively
  • Will not appear in the table of contents
  • Use these headings for subsections of an H2 article section, or when a section isnâ€™t in need of its own section in the table of contents.Â 

Add navigational elementsÂ 

Want to add elements that help organize and prioritize information in your article? In Zendesk, either natively or with a small bit of custom code, you can add:

  • Callout Blocks
  • Lists
  • Description Lists
  • Code Blocks
  • Tables
  • Tabs
  • Accordions
  • Links

Check out Internal Reference: Custom Zendesk Formatting Components for a full guide on adding these to your article.

More Uberflip writing resources

Want to take your knowledge of Uberflip's writing styleÂ further? Check out these sections of the Uberflip Content Guidelines:

  • Voice and tone
  • Grammar and mechanics
  • Frequently used words

item.title: Internal: Request a public article or article update
item.description:
Found a knowledge gap in Uberflipâ€™s Help Center? Letâ€™s document it for our users!

Before you begin

Article requests should fit within the scope of the Uberflip Help Center. A good help article topic will:Â 

  • be useful to multiple users (edge-cases should not be publicly documented)
  • not quickly become obsolete through upcoming product changes
  • Pertain directly to app.uberflip.com, an Uberflip app, or the integration process between Uberflip and third-party software
    Note: We do not document third-party software issues (i.e. issues in Marketo)Â Â 
  • not already be documented in the Help Center (be sure to check before making a request)

Note: Only articles and updates that fit the scope of the Uberflip Help Center will be added to the backlog.Â 

Â 

Request a new public articleÂ 

  1. Go to the #product-writing Slack channel
  2. Hover at the top of the channel and click Workflows

  3. Click Request Public Help DocÂ 
  4. Fill out the form that appears as accurately as you can (the more detail the better).
    To do so, you'll need to outline:
    • The issue users are experiencing
    • An estimate of how many users are experiencing the issue
    • The solution to the issueÂ 
    • Supporting documentation (i.e. Slack URL, internal docs, Jira tickets, etc.)[optional]Â 
  5. Click Submit

Your request will appear in the #product-writing channel, and will be reviewed by the Product Technical Writer as soon as possible.

Note

When articles are written is based on the articleâ€™s priority and the Technical Writerâ€™s bandwidth.Â 

Â 

Request an article update

If youâ€™ve found that an article has out of date steps, or information thatâ€™s no longer correct, let us know!Â 

Note

Small updates, like typos or broken hyperlinks, can be raised as a simple message in the #product-writing Slack channel. The steps below are for content changes only.

  1. Go to the #product-writing Slack channel
  2. Hover at the top of the channel and click Workflows
  3. Click Request Article Update Â 
  4. Fill out the form that appears as accurately as you can (the more detail the better).
    To do so, you'll need to outline :
    • The article that needs updating
    • The section(s) in the article that needs updating
    • The new info that replaces the outdated info
  5. Click Submit

Your request will appear in the #product-writing channel, and will be reviewed by the Product Technical Writer as soon as possible.

Â 

Boost a request ðŸ™Œ

Has a teammate made a request that you think is top-notch and sooooo needed? Add an emoji to show your support! ðŸ”¥ âž•

Have tips, suggestions, or supporting material to add to what your teammate included? Thread those on the request message.Â 

Crowdsourced additions like these help to boost the article's usefulness and priority. ðŸ’ª

item.title: Internal: Custom Zendesk Formatting Components
item.description:
This reference guide outlines the custom formatting components that are available our Zendesk Guide theme, along with instructions for use.

Â 

Introduction

Uberflip's Zendesk KB uses the customÂ Mink theme from Lotusthemes. This theme includes a variety of formatting components that are not natively available in Zendesk, such as callouts, accordions, tabs, etc.

In the Uberflip KB, the default appearance of many of these components has been customized for brand compliance. The purpose of this reference guide is to list the branded components, demonstrate their appearance, and provide instructions for use.

Note that not all components available in the theme have been branded. You can find a full list of available formatting components on the Lotusthemes KB here. While any of the formatting components not listed in this article are still technically compatible with this KB, they are not brand-compliant.

Â 

Usage

Each formatting component listed below falls into one of two categories:

  • Built-In: Some of the components are included with Zendesk, or replace the included version. You use these by clicking on the corresponding buttons in the Zendesk WYSISWYG text editor. All built-in components (available in the text editor) are brand-compliant; only those which are notable or have alternative styles are listed below.
  • Custom: All other components are custom, and do not have dedicated buttons. You use these by pasting a code snippet directly into the HTML source code of the article:

    (Be aware that the resulting formatting will usually not be visible in the text editor, only in the final article view.)

For each component listed in this article, correct usage is indicated via either the appropriate text editor button, or a code snippet.

Â 

Callout Blocks

Regular Callout

Example

Info

This is a regular callout, used for miscellaneous info.

To Use

<div class="callout">
  <h4 class="callout__title">Info</h4>
  <p>This is a regular callout, used for miscellaneous info.</p>
</div>

Tip Callout

Example

Tip

This is a tip callout, used for helpful tips.

To Use

<div class="callout callout--success">
  <h4 class="callout__title">Tip</h4>
  <p>This is a tip callout, used for hints and tips.</p>
</div>

Note Callout

Example

Note

This is a note callout, used to highlight informational notes.

To Use

<div class="callout callout--info">
  <h4 class="callout__title">Note</h4>
  <p>This is a note callout, used to highlight helpful notes.</p>
</div>

Caution Callout

Example

Caution

This is a caution callout, used for very important notes.

To Use

<div class="callout callout--warning">
  <h4 class="callout__title">Caution</h4>
  <p>This is a caution callout, used for very important notes.</p>
</div>

Warning Callout

Example

Warning

This is a warning callout, used for critical information that can cause damage/data loss if not heeded.

To Use

<div class="callout callout--danger">
  <h4 class="callout__title">Warning</h4>
  <p>This is a warning callout, used for critical information that can cause damage/data loss if not heeded.</p>
</div>

Â 

Lists

Ordered List

Example

  1. Ordered Item 1
  2. Ordered Item 2
    1. Ordered Indented Item
  3. Ordered Item 3
    • Unordered Indented Item

To Use

Text Editor Numbered list button:

Unordered List (Standard)

Example

  • Unordered Item 1
  • Unordered Item 1
    • Unordered Indented Item
  • Unordered Item 1
    1. Ordered Indented Item

ToÂ Use

Text Editor Bulleted list button:

Unordered List (Colored Bullets)

Example

  • Bullet One
  • Bullet Two
  • Bullet Three
    • Indented Bullet
  • Bullet Four

To Use

<ul class="list-bullet">
 <li>Bullet One</li>
 <li>Bullet Two</li>
 <li>Bullet Three</li>
 <li>Bullet Four</li>
</ul>

Â 

Description Lists

Standard

Example

Name of Item 1
This is where the description for this item goes.
It can also be across multiple paragraphs.
Name of Item 2
This is where the description for this item goes.
Name of Item 3
This is where the description for this item goes.

To Use

<dl>
 <dt>Name of Item 1</dt>
 <dd>This is where the description for this item goes.</dd>
 <dd>It can also be across multiple paragraphs.</dd>
 <dt>Name of Item 2</dt>
 <dd>This is where the description for this item goes.</dd>
 <dt>Name of Item 3</dt>
 <dd>This is where the description for this item goes.</dd>
</dl>

Horizontal

Example

Name of Item 1
This is where the description for this item goes.
It can also be across multiple paragraphs.
Name of Item 2
This is where the description for this item goes.
Name of Item 3
This is where the description for this item goes.

To Use

<dl class="dl-horizontal">
 <dt>Name of Item 1</dt>
 <dd>This is where the description for this item goes.</dd>
 <dd>It can also be across multiple paragraphs.</dd>
 <dt>Name of Item 2</dt>
 <dd>This is where the description for this item goes.</dd>
 <dt>Name of Item 3</dt>
 <dd>This is where the description for this item goes.</dd>
</dl>

Â 

Code

Code Block

Example

<head>
 <meta charset="utf-8">
 <meta name="viewport"
 content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, user-scalable=yes">
 <title>Hello World!</title>
</head>
<body>
Hello World!
</body>
</html>

To Use

<pre><code>
Code goes here
</code></pre>

or

<pre><code class='languagename'>
Code goes here
</code></pre>

Text editor Code block button can also be used:

Note that this onlyÂ inserts <pre> tags: if used, <code> tags must be manually inserted within <pre> tags as in code snippet above.

The theme uses highlight.js to highlight specific elements in code snippets based on the language being displayed. In many cases the language is detected and highlighted automatically, but you can also specify the language using <code class='languagename'> in place of <code>. A listing of all languages for which highlighting is available can be found here.

Inline Code

Example

This is an example sentence where I'm going to reference some inline code.

To Use

<code class="no-padding">insert inline code</code>

Â 

Tables

Standard

Example

Heading 1 Heading 2 Heading 3
100 400 700
200 500 800
300 600 900

To Use

Text Editor Table button:

Coloured Header

Example

Heading 1 Heading 2 Heading 3
100 400 700
200 500 800
300 600 900

To Use

As with Standard, but change <table> to <table class="table table--color-header">.

Bordered

Example

Heading 1 Heading 2 Heading 3
100 400 700
200 500 800
300 600 900

To Use

As with Standard, but change <table> to <table class="table table--bordered">.

Hover Coloured

Example

Heading 1 Heading 2 Heading 3
100 400 700
200 500 800
300 600 900

To Use

As with Standard, but change <table> to <table class="table table--striped">.

Â 

Tabs

Standard

Example

Tab 1Tab 2Tab 3Tab 4Tab 5
Tab 1 content goes here.
Tab 2 content goes here.
Tab 3 content goes here.
Tab 4 content goes here.
Tab 5 content goes here.

To Use

<div class="tabs">
 <div class="tabs-menu">
 <span class="tabs-link is-active">Tab 1</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 2</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 3</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 4</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 5</span>
 </div>
 <div class="tab">Tab 1 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 2 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 3 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 4 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 5 content goes here.</div>
</div>

Shaded

Example

Tab 1Tab 2Tab 3Tab 4Tab 5
Tab 1 content goes here.
Tab 2 content goes here.
Tab 3 content goes here.
Tab 4 content goes here.
Tab 5 content goes here.

To Use

<div class="tabs tabs--colored-1">
 <div class="tabs-menu">
 <span class="tabs-link is-active">Tab 1</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 2</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 3</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 4</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 5</span>
 </div>
 <div class="tab">Tab 1 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 2 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 3 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 4 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 5 content goes here.</div>
</div>

Coloured

Example

Tab 1Tab 2Tab 3Tab 4Tab 5
Tab 1 content goes here.
Tab 2 content goes here.
Tab 3 content goes here.
Tab 4 content goes here.
Tab 5 content goes here.

To Use

<div class="tabs tabs--colored-2">
 <div class="tabs-menu">
 <span class="tabs-link is-active">Tab 1</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 2</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 3</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 4</span>
 <span class="tabs-link">Tab 5</span>
 </div>
 <div class="tab">Tab 1 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 2 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 3 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 4 content goes here.</div>
 <div class="tab is-hidden">Tab 5 content goes here.</div>
</div>

Â 

Accordions

Caret (Shaded)

Example

Section 1

Section 1 content goes here.

Section 2

Section 2 content goes here.

Section 3

Section 3 content goes here.

Section 4

Section 4 content goes here.

Section 5

Section 5 content goes here.

To Use

<div class="accordion accordion--default">
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 1</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 1 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 2</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 2 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 3</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 3 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 4</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 4 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 5</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 5 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
</div>

Plus (Coloured)

Example

Section 1

Section 1 content goes here.

Section 2

Section 2 content goes here.

Section 3

Section 3 content goes here.

Section 4

Section 4 content goes here.

Section 5

Section 5 content goes here.

To Use

<div class="accordion accordion--colored">
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 1</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 1 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 2</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 2 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 3</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 3 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 4</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 4 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item">
 <div class="accordion__item-title">
 <strong>Section 5</strong>
 </div>
 <div class="accordion__item-content">
 <p>Section 5 content goes here.</p>
 </div>
 </div>
</div>

Â 

Links

Standard

Example

This is an example of a standard link.

To Use

Text EditorÂ Insert/edit link button:

Button

Example

Click Here!

To Use

<a class="btn btn--primary" href="https://help.uberflip.com" target="_blank">
  Click Here!
</a>
